dialogue.text: The therapy group meets in the spiral garden. 'We're not here to answer your questions,' the facilitator says, 'but to help you fall in love with them.'
I spent forty years being 'successful businessman.' Now that identity is gone and I'm terrified of the emptiness.
What if the emptiness is spaciousness? Room for something new to emerge?
I was so angry at uncertainty. But the certainty I demanded was killing me.
Thank god. I'm so tired of people telling me who I should be.
But at night, the questions came anyway. I was fighting myself.
Some relationships are meant to last. Your relationship with 'What am I?' might be the most enduring one you'll ever have.

psychological_notes: Shows evolution of therapeutic practice to embrace rather than resolve existential uncertainty. Marcus Sterling's presence demonstrates how even strongest resistance can transform. Group discovers uncertainty as opportunity rather than affliction. Therapy helps develop affectionate relationship with questions.
philosophical_underpinning: Questions as lifelong companions deserving love not resolution
therapeutic_direction: Uncertainty as wellness rather than illness
